title: Wednesday, 22nd November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Good budget.

BE11:04am

Anything happening today then? Quick look at the email for ideas.

BE11:04am

11:04 am
BE11:04am

So, quite budgety.

BE11:04am

C of the E Philip H starts up at 12.30pm, right after PM's questions, of course.

BE11:05am

Should we quote an economist here, to tell us that political influences are important as economic ones for Philip Hammond as he presents the first Autumn Budget?

11:05 am
BE11:06am

Here's Dermot O’Leary at Goodbody.

BE11:06am

Political influences are important as economic ones as Philip Hammond presents the first Autumn Budget in the UK today.

BE11:06am

Thumbs up

11:06 am
BE11:06am

While the first budget of a new government often contains as much of the hard decisions as possible early in a new term, the precarious position of the current Tory government mean that this is not the case this time around. Instead, the narrative going into today appears to be on ending austerity and resolving perceived inter-generational inequity.

BE11:06am

While the Chancellor is being pressurised to take a more aggressive approach on the fiscal front, a downgrade to medium-term growth forecasts by the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) is likely to limit room for manoeuvre. It is widely expected that this downgrade will stem from further reductions in expected productivity growth, a constant theme in recent years. This could reduce most of the £26bn in fiscal headroom that was thought to be available to the Chancellor at the time of the March budget if a target of a deficit of just 2% of GDP was to be achieved by 2021-2022.

BE11:06am

At a minimum, the Chancellor must make room for some of the pledges that have been made since the election. These include increased housing output (£0.5bn p.a.), the DUP deal (£0.5bn p.a.), the U-turn on national insurance for the self-employed (£0.5bn p.a.) and increased public sector pay (£2.6bn). While there may be some further small giveaways and plenty of rhetoric about the strength of the UK economy, we would expect Chancellor Hammond to largely stick to his “steady as she goes” persona, despite the daggers that appear to be pointed in his direction.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

And you remembr that cribsheet from Liberum we shared yesterday going though the policy leaks?

BE11:07am

Here it is again.

BE11:07am

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Right click and open in new window if you want to be able to read that.

BE11:07am

Though I totally sympathise if you don't.

undefined
11:08 am
BE11:08am

(@Flaneur: true, unless there's a European land war to balance out the voter demographics.)

BE11:09am

But we can't spend an hour on budget preview. We simply can't.

BE11:09am

Because there are sausages to talk about.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

BE11:10am

Yes! 115 pages from Berenberg on collagen sausage skins!

BE11:10am

And, honestly, it's a great read.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

They're sellers of Devro and buyers of Viscofan, BTW.

BE11:10am

Artificial casings industry in a nutshell: With a global market size of cEUR2.2bn, the artificial sausage casings industry is a niche area within the wider speciality ingredient space. It is highly-consolidated, with the top eight players holding an 85% share, and has high entry barriers due to sophisticated production requirements, high investment levels and economies of scale, resulting in attractive profitability.

BE11:12am

Devro was classed as a growth stock coming out of the GFS, you'll remember, when processed pork was exciting.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Then it all went a bit wrong.

BE11:12am

The casings industry has slowed dramatically since 2014, driven by a combination of cyclical and structural factors. Cyclically, an oversupply of collagen in China has resulted in heavy discounting and contract losses for some players, while weak macro conditions and FX headwinds in Latin America resulted in a big drop in casings demand in 2016. Structurally, the casings industry is being affected by the slowing consumption of processed meat products in developed regions, slowing conversion from animal gut to collagen, as well as increasing pricing headwinds from processed meat industry consolidation. We forecast 3% industry growth CAGR to 2020 – a recovery relative to the previous three years, as cyclical factors abate, but below the historical mid-single-digit levels.

BE11:13am

Berenberg's argument is to sell developed markets, because they're getting less keen on a bit of sausage. And buy China and Latin America, where they're just coming round to a bit of sausage.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And -- unlike a sausage! -- their note is absolutely stuffed full of good stuff.

BE11:13am

BE11:13am

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Sell Devro, tho.

BE11:14am

While Devro has pioneered the development of collagen for sausage casings, leading the wave of meat processor conversion, we believe it is now in a structurally challenged position for growth, with a relatively unattractive sales exposure to slowing developed markets and weak market positions and a sub-optimal manufacturing footprint in emerging markets. Having completed an intensive GBP110m capital investment programme in 2016, we believe that more capital commitment will be necessary in the near term to optimise Devro’s capacity. With a high debt profile and growing pension deficit, we expect FCF pressures over the next few years and see significant downside risk to current market forecasts. Devro trades on 17x 2018E P/E for a 5% three-year EPS CAGR.

Devro PLC (DVO:LSE): Last: 217.50, down 17 (-7.25%), High: 227.00, Low: 215.00, Volume: 114.64k
11:14 am
BE11:15am

Switch to Viscofan.

BE11:15am

In an industry with significant economies of scale, Viscofan is the unprecedented market leader, with a global market share that is more than double the size of its closest competitor. With a best-in-class manufacturing footprint, more than 50% sales exposure to emerging markets, where Viscofan is the market leader, and a uniquely diversified product portfolio, we believe that Viscofan is set to grow above-market and continue gaining share. With a net cash position on the balance sheet at FY 2018E, Viscofan is in a comfortable position to continue consolidating the industry, further expanding its scale. Having de-rated to a 12% discount relative to the European food sector on the back of industry headwinds in 2016, we think that the market now discounts a more attractive growth profile as well as further potential for EPS-accretive M&A and enhanced shareholder returns. Viscofan trades on 17.6x 2018E P/E for a 7% three-year EPS CAGR.

undefined
11:16 am
BE11:16am

(@alewis: no one's "stuck" with a lorne sausage. They're blessed with it.)

BE11:17am

I think we might've peaked too early.

BE11:17am

Nevertheless, let's head upwards into the movers.

11:17 am
Thomas Cook Group plc (TCG:LSE): Last: 110.50, down 11.2 (-9.20%), High: 114.50, Low: 104.10, Volume: 11.82m
BE11:18am

UK weak.

BE11:18am

Headline is in line, pretty much, but that disguises a collapse in UK earnings and a big hit to margins.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

And in the background we've also got this kind of thing: http://www.mirror....day-deals-11557094

BE11:20am

Thomas Cook Black Friday deals kick off early with £200 off summer 2018 breaks including all-inclusive holidays

BE11:20am

...... which is, uh, an advert.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

....... which was used for a drop intro in Opening Quote this morning: https://ftalphavil...hitman-to-quit-hp/

BE11:20am

..... which was then picked up by Bloomberg.

BE11:21am

Separately, FT Alphaville reports that Thomas Cook is offering Black Friday discounts a few days early, and such early price cutting may be a warning sign

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Financial news, eh? What a bloody pantomime.

BE11:21am

Anyway, back to the numbers.

BE11:22am

The noises from the company on current trading are intended to reassure so it looks like 2018 consensus is only coming down by about 5%.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:23am

FY17 estimates slightly beaten but UK softer than expected. FY17 EBIT £330m (1% ahead of company consensus, 2% ahead of Barclays forecasts). EPS of 9.3p, 6% lower than company consensus due to higher than expected finance charge of £41m vs. £23m last year. In terms of the mix, the Tour Operator EBIT is flat Year on Year meaning the growth was generated by the airline business with a strong performance from Condor (EBIT of £12m vs. consensus £5m). However, we think the focus will be on the soft UK margin of 4.5% vs. consensus 6.3% and Barclays 6.2%. This is much worse than expected despite TCG flagging margin pressure through the year. TCG saw input cost inflation and higher capacity in the UK and the end of the year was impacted negatively by hurricanes and illness claims. The major issue is exposure to Spain (c. 44% of UK business) – going forward TCG needs to remix capacity away from Spain. We think prices for holidays to Spain will need to rise 5-10% in FY18 to keep margins flat: a tough ask in a tough market. There is no change to guidance for FY18. We note that Net Debt of £40m was £18m better than company consensus (and £5m better than Barclays), highlighting that cash flow dynamics are relatively robust but we note there was a material working capital inflow which might be one off in nature. TCG trades on 10.4x cal18E P/E and a 9% FCF yield.

BE11:23am

And Panmure ..........

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Winter 2017/18 is 58% sold with group bookings +5% (was 3%) and pricing +2% (unch). Summer 2018 has started well with overall holiday bookings and pricing ahead of last year, helped by demand picking up for Turkey and Egypt and probably (but not specified) some near-term help from the demise of Monarch, Air Berlin, Alitalia (?) and Ryanair’s own goal. The UK programme is 27% sold, with bookings +2% and pricing +6%, driven by input cost inflation. TCG says it is well-positioned to achieve FY EBIT in line with market expectations: consensus sits at £354m EBIT (PGe £352m), with continued recovery in Condor and positive momentum in Continental Europe and Northern Europe tour operating. But management is implemented a set of actions to return the UK tour operator business to its former profitable growth trajectory. This incremental cautious is the key area of focus for investors today.

BE11:24am

nvestment case. We recently upgraded TCG to HOLD on the basis of improving prospects on three fronts: 1) Condor’s £35m profit improvement target now looks more achievable, helped by Air Berlin disruption in Germany; 2) forecasts expectations more comfortable (per above comments); and 3) product strategy progress, both organic (focused own-brand & differentiated hotel offering) and via strategic alliances: Expedia (outsourcing tail of undifferentiated hotels), LMEY (expand own-brand hotel portfolio), Fosun/China. But lingering concerns prevent us from being constructive on the shares at this level: I) we assume UK and Nordics margins have peaked; and II) FX/fuel hedging is rolling off leaving the UK business needing to raise holiday prices (high single digits?) to offset COGS inflation, levelling the playing field with OTAs. Hence our HOLD rating.

BE11:25am

Sector wise ...........

11:25 am
Tui AG (TUI:LSE): Last: 1,322, down 13 (-0.97%), High: 1,330, Low: 1,286, Volume: 770.91k
On The Beach Group PLC (OTB:LSE): Last: 385.75, up 0.5 (+0.13%), High: 388.50, Low: 384.50, Volume: 76.20k
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 17.80, down 0.18 (-1.00%), High: 18.05, Low: 17.77, Volume: 403.53k
11:26 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,356, up 13 (+0.97%), High: 1,374, Low: 1,347, Volume: 892.00k
BE11:27am

Who turned positive on EasyJet this morning?

BE11:27am

Investec. That was it.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Results were in line with guidance, and disappointing compared to peers, but guidance for FY18 is encouraging and the potential acquisition of Air Berlin would give easyJet another market leading position. Yields have improved due to the cessation of insolvent airline flights and Ryanair cancellations and with further consolidation and restructuring likely, we take a more positive view on yield. We therefore increase our TP to 1600p and upgrade to BUY.

undefined
BE11:29am

Sage, of all things, requested.

11:29 am
Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 788.00, up 13 (+1.68%), High: 808.50, Low: 757.00, Volume: 2.14m
BE11:03am

Welcome to Budget Budget, FT Alphaville's daily budget with the budget and the budget and budget budget budget.

BE11:31am

2018 guidance -- 8% organic rev growth and 27.5% op margin -- is below some expectations but seems not to have spooked the buyside.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

As in, the margin guidance, I should make clear. Revenue guidance is better.

BE11:32am

And I'm delighted to say that George O'Connor, ex Panmure, has reappeared at Stifel. Because his approach to writing a results note is ..... well, it's a break from the norm.

BE11:32am

Sage: Finals – “Never give a sword to a man who can’t dance”

11:32 am
BE11:33am

............ go on.

BE11:33am

Confucius tells us that about the responsibility of power – a man who can’t dance will collide with others, a man with no grace should not be entrusted with military might. And so CEO Stephen Kelly and team ‘New Sage’ deliver a dancing set of final results nicely ahead of expectations. For us, the standout is the cash with net debt to £813m. Also note an upbeat outlook statement as Mr Kelly flags up 8% organic revenue growth. Ahead of meeting management this morning, we raise our 2018E forecasts primarily to reflect the beat (better revenue). Confucius also tells us that “The man who moves a mountain begins by carrying away small stones.” As we look for evidence of the Sage turnaround and restructuring, there are lots of stones moving around – and we note (i) solid progress on ACV for Sage Live and Sage One and (ii) recurring revenue to 37% of total from 22% YoY. Yes, there are niggles: adds on new customers, no improvement to renewal rates, the
NPS progress positive but from a low base and margin in International. Tech recoveries are about the three ‘Ps’ – product, people and process – and while we should get more on these at the CMD (25 January), these final results are far more than a curtain raiser. The forecast changes increase our target price to 863p (from 809p). We retain our Buy rating.

BE11:34am

And Barclays. Also a good, though slightly more plain, read.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

The first three years of Sage’s transition period have been tougher than originally anticipated, in our view, and Sage in FY17 did not manage to deliver any meaningful growth acceleration on an underlying basis. It has significantly restructured the cost base, but the underlying margin is flat. As a result Sage altered its strategy and resorted to an inorganic strategy and divested the US payment business and acquired SaaS businesses Intacct and Fairsail. The divestment did flatter the reported FY organic growth (6.6%) by c. 0.7% and, on an underlying basis, the growth therefore decelerated slightly on last year (6.1%). For FY18 it guides for 8% organic revenue growth and a margin of c. 27.5%. While these look encouraging, this is purely from inorganic development and does not require an underlying improvement.

Overall this is very much in line with our expectations and the reason for our upgrade in September. Underlying there is little improvement noticeable, but optically the growth is starting to look attractive. The stock reaction today will be largely driven by CEO Kelly’s ability to convince investors that the next stage of the transition will deliver the promised underlying improvement in KPIs.

undefined
BE11:36am

ROTR, the visa thing for the restaurant trade is endlessly fascinating.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

In terms of listed companies, Fulham Shore's the obvious exposure point.

Fulham Shore PLC (FUL:LSE): Last: 12.00, down 0.125 (-1.03%), High: 12.25, Low: 12.00, Volume: 197.54k
BE11:37am

... though I'd also note Shaftesbury.

11:37 am
Shaftesbury PLC (SHB:LSE): Last: 993.00, no change, High: 994.50, Low: 990.00, Volume: 32.57k
BE11:37am

(@Mouselet: I should italicise things when I'm being sincere.)

BE11:39am

....... which owns a lot of Chinatown, of course, where knowing whether there will be enough people will be in the kitchen of a Saturday is an endless gamble.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Though I imagine Shaftesbury would rather that Chinatown was full of Costas and All Bar Ones, so .... whatever.

BE11:40am

(@ROTR: I was being sincere! You can be fascinating, occasionally.)

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

(Also, @ROTR: mentioned in the past that NXT, the mostly useless Aim-listed maker of flat speakers, would go up and down based on the results just reported by Next, the retailer, as they had very similar EPIC codes. That's my favourite name confusion example.)

BE11:42am

Okay, back to stuff.

BE11:42am

Kingfisher mentioned on the right.

11:42 am
Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 319.30, up 10.8 (+3.50%), High: 319.80, Low: 312.00, Volume: 6.72m
BE11:43am

.... as in the B&Q owner, not the fragmented Indian conglomerate of some dubiousness.

BE11:43am

Jefferies pushing.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Investment attractions are improving as disruption reduces and evidence of +ve sales response to ONE product builds. The potential for a +ve inflection in French market share and resilience to UK cyclical risks should be better valued. Our upgrade to Buy with a 400p PT presumes investors will be willing to pay a c.13x forward PE (6.6% FCY) a year from now.

BE11:44am

The balance of risk on ONE is reducing... as evidence of a strong sales response to new
product ranges is improving and more recent store checks confirm moderating disruption
from unified launches. The scale of change at Kingfisher remains meaningful, but the pitfalls to profit expectations are reducing. We have measured where unified price points land, and
found them to sharply improve the value attraction of the KGF proposition in both France
and the UK. The B&Q digital offering looks much improved, highlighting another area of major support for France in 2018. Unified driven deflation should moderate from Q2 next year.

BE11:45am

Skipping the bit about France.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

KGF remains vulnerable to UK macro uncertainties. However, these look unlikely to be accompanied by the incremental headwind of a recovering Bunnings. Store visits continue to highlight poor execution in legacy Homebase locations, with Bunnings rebrands translating less effectively in standard-sized Homebase stores. In addition, Screwfix's multi-channel excellence remains unmatched and should remain a key driver for further KGF share gains.

BE11:45am

Buy up to 400p, equating to cal 2019 P/E of 12.7x, 6.6% FCY backed by 11% EPS CAGR
and a cumulative 3yr FC (18/19 to 20/21) of greater than £1.5bn (with an annual exit rate of £0.7bn). This would compare to an equity base which we estimate at c.£6bn (at today's share price on our forecast exit rate of share count).

undefined
11:46 am
BE11:47am

ROTR, I'm sure we did some stuff on self-driving cars and insurance premiums a while ago.

BE11:48am

The gist -- I think from Morgan Stanley, or possibly UBS? -- was that car insurance was a dying business as policies will have to be written by OEMs.

BE11:49am

Though you're looking at a decade or two before this becomes a real problem for investors, so probably not worth building into the terminal value yet.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

There was a lot of stuff about totally autonomous versus souped up cruise control, and how the latter will arrive long before the former. Anyway, it's in the archive somewhere.

BE11:50am

Otherwise, read Iz.

undefined
11:50 am
BE11:51am

What else, then?

BE11:51am

JP Morgan has a note on Reckitt that I struggled to get too far though.

BE11:52am

In light of the low visibility on earnings and optionalities building up on M&A/disposals we run a scenario analysis to stress test valuation as RB's shares are now trading at a historical discount to peers following earnings cut since Q217. We conclude that a range of outcomes should lead to a valuation range of £64 to £90 (for access to our scenario analysis please contact us). In other words we see now the risk/reward skewed to the upside. While the top end of our valuation range is likely to be weighed on the progress of M&A/disposals on a 12-18 month basis, we see a short term relief potential to £75, hence our upgrade to Overweight.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

(@Waynej: yeah, it is.)

BE11:53am

Gradually, they come towards an argument.

BE11:53am

The creation of two separate divisions is creating options for structural portfolio shifts as we consider a potential disposal of H/H (we argue RB is not the best owner any more given share losses), the potential reinvestment in M&A in Health/Nutrition H/N or the creation of a standalone H/N business, in a category that will keep consolidating over time. Any newsflow on M&A/disposals will likely focus the market on the value unlocking from these options.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

So ........

BE11:54am

Considering the flex in our EPS forecasts, we assess fair value around several scenarios:
1) on a standalone basis – which is our core base for now, 2) a potential disposal of HH and buying of Pfizer OTC, 3) a SOTP. We derive a valuation range of £64-90, leaving the risk/rewards skewed to the upside. Over the next six months, a reassurance that EPS is not rebased further (as management presents its new division structure) and a rebound in LFL growth should drive the valuation multiples back to industry averages (versus a 16% EPS discount today) to JPM Dec18 TP of £75. We see further upside to the higher end of the range, although these will be weighed on the progress of M&A/disposals on a 12-18 month view.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 6,551, up 150 (+2.34%), High: 6,582, Low: 6,492, Volume: 923.65k
11:54 am
undefined
BE11:55am

Hey, folk on the left, I note you seem to be debating autonomous cars and takeaways. Yet you've not considered the obvious synergy here.

BE11:56am

An autonomously piloted mobile kitchen that makes chicken chow mien, delivering it on demand. Proper disruption.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Anyway, what else before we hunker down for budget-geddon?

BE11:58am

SSP mentioned above somehere. Record high.

BE11:59am

And special divi.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

(@wayneJ: you make a good point. I'm discombobulated.)

BE12:00pm

£100m back to shareholders, which is a wee bit of an odd thing for a company that allegedly has so much road in front of it to grow into.

BE12:01pm

Otherwise, EBIT beats by about 3%, outlook is in line.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

(@GBKrona, interesting possibly but not the best in terms of investment advice...)

BE12:01pm

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE12:02pm

SSP’s FY17 results are ahead of our expectations with EBIT of £163m (+27% constant FX, MSe /consensus £158m) and EPS of 20.3p (+32%, MSe 19.3p, cons 19.6p). Organic sales grew by 8.8% (MSe and prior announcement 8.5%), implying 12.8% in Q4. EBIT margins rose 70bps (MSe +50bps) or 50bps underlying, with a strong beat in the UK (+160bps to 10.4%) more than offsetting misses in North America (-90bps) and ROW (-130bps) which were impacted by higher D&A on contract ramps. The dividend was hiked 50% to 8.1p (MSe 6.5p, cons 6.9p), and the company announced a £100m special dividend and share consolidation, which will take leverage from 1.0x to the low end of its 1.5-2.0x target. This is only 1-2% EPS enhancing given the high multiple the shares trade on. The outlook is solid with an “encouraging” pipeline of new contracts, but the company is expecting lower sales growth (2-3% LfL, 3% net contract gains) and slower margin expansion (20bps), and FX has moved slightly against it (1% headwind for FY18). For FY18e we model 5.6% organic sales growth and +30bps to margins (£174m EBIT, cons £171m), and the company sees FY18 EBIT consensus moving up to c. £175m with EPS of c. 22p (MSe 21p) including the special dividend share consolidation.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

(@Boncoeur: I think you've misspelled "opposite" as "equivalent".)

BE12:03pm

And Numis.

BE12:03pm

Outlook & forecasts: SSP suggests FY18 has started in line with expectations: it typically provides cautious guidance early in the year and sees subsequent upgrades.
Unsurprisingly they have guided to a slightly slower lfl revenue growth next year (NUMe
2.3% vs 3.1%). Our FY18 assumption for new units of 2.5% is also conservative. Management expects to grow EBIT margins by 20bp in FY18, suggesting upside to our 6.8% estimate. As a result we expect consensus EPS to increase by 3-4% on an underlying basis, prior to the 3% accretion from today's capital return.
Valuation & recommendation: Prior to revisions SSP trades on a CY18E EV/EBITDA
of 11.5x and FCF yield of 5% We remain positive on the combination of structural growth,
margin upside and strong management.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Still seems odd to me that SSP's on on, what, 31 times earnings and 7 times book even though it's to a reasonable extent a play on rail traffic volumes..

BE12:06pm

Best not pick over the argument again though.

undefined
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Hey, look at the time.

BE12:07pm

Thanks to the ROTR for moving the conversation onto my weight and/or density.

BE12:08pm

We'll close up now. Here's the live coverage of the budget: https://www.ft.com...-b781-794ce08b24dc

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Actually, try this one: https://www.ft.com...-b065-8b1dc2a6a049

BE12:08pm

Currently zero comments on that page so get in quick and start an argument.

BE12:09pm

Meanwhile, we'll be back tomorrow. Afternoon all.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Results are fine. Average. Ordinary.
